The try-outs for the Varsity debating teams were held on Friday
in the Assembly Hall. The men
selected to represent the University
in the annual triangular debate were
T. J. Tingley, H. C. Coffin, J. S.
Friedenwald and H. M. Blalock.
The alternates are M. G. Gichner
and R. Oppenheimer.
The tentative plans of the teams
are for Tingley (chairman), Coffin
and Oppenheimer (alternate) to go
to Virginia to debate the team from
North Carolina—the Hopkins men
upholding the affirmative. In this
case Friedenwald (chairman), Blalock and Gichner (alternate) will
go tp North Carolina to debate Virginia, where Hopkins has the negative of the question.
'Dr. French expressed himself as.
highly gratified with the quality of
the try-out and especially with the
number of men who contested.
More men participated in these tryouts than in any past few years.
Tingley, the chairman of the
affirmative team, is well known in
Hopkins debating circles. He has
been a member of the Adams team
for the past three years, on his
class team twice, on each occasion
lie was successful, and on the winning Varsity team of last year.
Coffin has been on his class team for
two years, but this is his first appearance on the Varsity. Friedenwald, 'to, is comparatively unknown in Hopkins debating, but
made a very good impression in
the try-outs. Blalock, a graduate
student in political science, was a
member of debating teams at the
University of North Carolina. He
is a member of the honorary debating fraternity, the same one that
recently made an effort to establish
a chapter at Hopkins.
There is every reason to believe
that the teams will be succesful, and
will maintain thg Hopkins debating
tradition of unbroken victory, which
the contests of the past three years
has established.

By overwhelmingly defeatin
Swarthmore College last Saturda
in the latter's pool, 4972 points WI
192, the swiming team evened up
matters somewhat with the Pennsyli
vanians for their victory in football,
last fall at Homewood. As Swarth7
more was one of the two teams to
defeat the Black and Blue on the
gridiron, Hopkins tankmen werc
determined to take a fall out b
their opponents, and how well
theyl
succeeded is indicated by the score;
Hopkins started off with a rush
by annexing the 200-yard relay:
Woodward, swimming first for the
Black and Blue, opened a lead
which was increased by his teammates to a safe margin. In the
next event, the plunge for distance,
'Swarthmore secured her only first
place, Dowdell winning with a fine
plunge of 66 feet 3 inches. Penneman, the only Hopkins representative in this event, was a good second
with a distance of 60 feet 10 inches.
The 50-yard dash found Rowland
of Hopkins, the individual star of
the meet, romping off with first
place in good time, with Marshall
close behind.
In the fancy diving, Captain Hofman showed his usual brilliant
form and won by a wide margin.
Murch of Swarthmore and McCormick for Hopkins fought it out for
second place, the former finally winning by the narrow margin of 3
points. The next event, the 50yard breast stroke, saw Rowland
again in the lead, with Ginsberg..
also of Hopkins, second. McCormick and Kirk found little difficulty
in winning 8 more points for the
Black and Blue by placing first and
second respectively in the 200-yard
swim. Woodward, Hopkins' only
entrant in the 50-yard back stroke.
found little difficulty in winning this
race by several yards. In the 10oyard dash, Rowland won his third
first place by swimming a beautiful
race. Doyle of Swarthmore placed
second, while Marshall and Pearson
swam a dead heat for the third position.
Hopkins will swim Haverford
College Saturday night in Baltimore at the Central Young Men's
Christian Association, and if the
form so far displayed by the Black
and Blue tankmen is continued,
another Pennsylvania college will
Probably be repaid for her football
victory.

Editor Tingley Pleased with Work Done
on Hullabaloo—Drawings Complimented by the Engraver—All
Photographs Finished.

The work on the 1916 Hullabaloo
has progressed so well that Editorin-chief Tingley expects to have the
book issued shortly before May 15.
Almost all the articles have been
written and the rest of the material
is now coming in rapidly.
During- the past week representatives of the White Studio of New
York have been engaged in taking
photographs of the members of the
Senior Class, THE-NEws-LF,TTER
Board, the Student Council, the
fraternities, the Athletic Board and
other Hopkins organizations and
clubs. The pictures are being taken
on the top floor of the physics
laboratory, which has been fitted
up as a studio. The pictures of the
various classes were taken at Gilman Hall, Homewood, on last Saturday and the early part of this
week. Although all the photographic work is expected to be completed by today (February 15),
if anything more .has to be done,
it will be attended to by D. R. Vickers, photographic editor of the Hullabaloo.
Some very excellent drawings
have been produced, which have
been complimented by the engraver.
As soon as the cuts for the lacrosSe,
baseball and tennis sections are
sent in, the number of necessary
drawings will be complete. The
Hullabaloo Board urges all to subscribe at once as the price N'ill soon
be raised. At present the price in
full for one copy is $2, if the subscription is entered and remitted
before March 15, 1916. After that
date the subscription price will be
raised to $2.50.

BASEBALL ORGANIZES THURSDAY

re MacKenzie Bakery

Addresses to Be Made and Team's Needs
to Be Discussed -Prospects for
Successful Season Unusually Bright.

JOHN W. RUSSEI.I., Prop.

226 WEST FRANKLIN STREET
622 NORTH EUTAW STREET

The baseball organization meeting for the season of 1916 will be
held in the trophy room of the gymnasium on Thursday, February 24,.
at 5 o'clock. Captain Lewis R.
Ewing will preside and speeches
will be made by the following: Mr.
Robertson Griswold, Dr. Thomas
R. Brown, Dr. Robert B. Roulston,
Dr. Ronald T. Abercrombie, Coach
Hooper and Manager Allan K.
Chalmers. Some of the old players
are also expected to make a few
remarks and interesting reminiscences will be brought back to the
minds of baseball men of former
years.
The prospects for a championship team are exceptionally bright,
Last year Hopkins carried off the
Maryland baseball championship
by winning every State game. Outside the State, defeat was suffered
at the hands of Gettysburg and
Catholic University. A chance to
even the score with Gettysburg will
be afforded the team at the opening game of the season, but Catholic University is not on this year's
schedule.
Material for the team is promisinf.;. Butler and "Butts- Sutton
are the only regulars of last year's
team who are lost. On the other
hand, several experienced men who
were unable to play last year have
promised t) come out this spring.
Both the medical school and the
Freshman Class are expected to
offer sine valuable players. The
first practice will he held in the cage
and will be continued there until
the weather becomes favorable for
work at 1 lornewood.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEB. 14, 1916.
The Banquets.

ti

With the peaceful and law-abiding banquets of the last two years
to look back upon, it might be
deemed unnecessary to again bring
before the attention of the student
body the strong advisability of such
proceedings. Yet rumors have
been afloat that this year the turbulent banquets of former days will
be revived.
THE NEWS-LETTER is not inclined to put credence in such
rumors—it has too high an opinion
of the calibre of the men and the
spirit of the two lower classes to
believe that either freshmen or
sophomores would have so little regard for the good name of the University as to jeopardize it by any
such a course of action. The belief that, in order to evidence class
spirit, it is vitally necessary to kidnap members of another class on
the night of this banquet, has disappeared. Hopkins has come to
realize that the dangerous notoriety
which follows such expressions of
undergraduate exuberance harms
the University far more than any
mythical gain in class spirit might
be supposed to benefit it.
THE NEWS-LETTER believes in
class spirit, believes in it firmly and
whale-heartedly, and it believes
that such manifestations as have.at-

As a whole the Hopkins team
made a very able showing and the
rooters have every reason to expect that their efforts will be exerted in behalf of a winning team

As regards the relay, the result
must be largely accorded to one of
those unfortunate occurrences which
every track man learns to expect
from time to time, and which serve
to show how many fine points there
are to be observed. The third man
on the team, being a little too anxious to get away failed on the running start to allow himself to be
touched within the prescribed distance of 20 feet. This not only
necessitated his slowing up to be
touched-off and the loss of considerable ground, but also disqualified his
team. The men finished the race
in sportsmanlike fashion and took
their licking with good grace.

JUNIOR TEAM HEADING LEAGUE
Games in Interclass Basket-Ball League
Causing Much Interest Improvement Is Being Shown in
All the Teams.

Interclass contests in basket-ball
have been. held before at Hopkins,
but never has there been such interest and enthusiasm shown as marks
the present games in the gymnasium every Tuesday and Thursday
at 5 o'clock P. M. Each class is
represented by a team. Practically
all of the scheduled games from
January 8 have been played and
the series will continue until February 29, 1916.
The juniors are heading the list
as to points, but their playing in the
last two games has not been up .to
the pace which they set at the commencement of the series. The good
Work of Brooks and the all-around
Playing of P. Sutton are valuable
assets to the team. McKewen has
also shown ability in his fast offensive work. The success of the juniors can be attributed to their consistent team work and individual

all drawn good sized crowds. The
student body has taken a decided

much enthusiasm is being shown.
Adherents of the sport predict that
basket-ball in Hopkins may become
a recognized sport in the near future.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 14, 1916.

6
MUSEUM TO BE MOVED IN JUNE

STUDENTS IGNORANT OF THE WAR

Valuable Collection of Archaeological
Antiquities to Be Lodged in Academic
Building at Homewood Great
Care to Be Taken in Moving.

Tests of Bowdoin, Williams and New
York University Reveal Fact That
Students Know Little About
Presant History.

The transportation of the collection in the Archaeological Museum
in McCoy Hall to Homewood will
probably take place in June. Owing
to the fragility of the specimens
and their great value, great care
will have to be taken in their moving. Consequently a number of the
articles, including the collection of
Roman and Greek coins which are
valued at $5,00o, will have to be
carried out by hand.
Dr. Robinson and Dr. Magoffin,
who are in charge of the museum,
are already making their plans.
Each specimen will have to be catalogued and labelled, and then be
boxed by professional packers. The
well-preserved articles, such as
some of the vases and other forms
of pottery, the inscriptions and
marble fragments, can be packed in
excelsior in barrels and boxes and
transported in wagons. The delicate bronzes, the Roman glassware, and some of the more fragile
pieces of pottery, however, will
have to be packed with especial
care, and it is doubtful whether
these can be intrusted to the packers for delivery. Likewise great
care will be required in the packing of the ancient manuscripts and
the mummy, which, on account of
its great age, is in a rather crumbling condition.
The room next to the Donovan
Room in the Academic building at
Homewood is to be the future home
of the collection. Dr. Robinson
hopes to buy new steel cases of the
latest type and have them installed
in this room, but, owing to the present lack of money, it is very doubtful whether this can be accomplished before the removal.

As a result of tests put to the
students of several institutions,
among which were Bowdoin, Williams and New York University,
it has been ascertained that there
exists a pronounced ignorance
among- the students of those universities as to important details of the
European War. This ignorance has
been taken as a manifestation of the
general tendency on the part of the
public to neglect a close study of
affairs in Europe; but, at the same
time, it has called forth severe condemnations of student intelligence.
Some of the questions asked by
members of the faculty at both New
York University and Bowdoin College were as follows:
Where is Gallipoli?
What is the capital of Bulgaria?
In what country is Salonika?
On what sea is Montenegro?
Who is the Prime Minister of
England?
Who is Bethman-Hollweg?
Who is Venizelos?
Who is Poincare?
Who is Briand?
Who is von Hindenberg?
Who is Vivani ?
Name the ruler of Turkey
Name the ruler of Bulgaria.
Some rather surprising answers
were received in the examinations.
One student said that the ruler of
Italy was Victor Emmanuel XXIX ;
another said that Poincare was a
French artist. Forty-two out of
fifty-three students at Bowdoin were
unable to tell in what country Saionika was situated ; and only twenty-three out of a class of fifty-three
could name the ruler of Greece.
In answering the question, "Who
is Venizelos ?" some students said
that he was a French general, others that he was a Mexican rebel.
The name of the commander of the
French army was given as anything
from "Joffery" to "Jeofrey."
The general result of the examination at the University of New
York was this:
"None answered all of the inquiries correctly, while only three obta(ned a grade above 90 per cent.
Of a class of twenty-three freshmen, nine failed, while the average
rank was 63 per cent. Another
class of the same number of freshmen averaged only 52 per cent., and
tbirteen failed to pass, while a class
made up of upper-classmen did as
poorly and averaged a grade of
only 61 per cent."

A Matter of Timing.

A minister in the Highlands of
Scotland found one of his parishioners intoxicated. Next day he
called to reprove him for it.
"It was wrong to get drunk," said
the parson.
"I ken that," said the guilty person, "but then I dinna drink as
meikle as you do."
"Why, sir, how .is that ?"
"Why, gin it please ye, dinna ye
ave take a glass o' whiskey and
water after (limier ?"
"Why, yes, Jemmy; sure, I take
a glass of whiskey after dinner,
merely to aid digestion."
"And dinna ye take a glass o'
toddy every night when ye are
ganging to bed?"
"Yes ; to be sure ; I just take a month. I only get paid once a
little toddy every night to help me month, and then if I'd take sixty
to sleep."

The try-outs for the Varsity debating teams were held on Friday
in the Assembly Hall. The men
selected to represent the University
in the annual triangular debate were
T. J. Tingley, H. C. Coffin, J. S.
Friedenwald and H. M. Blalock.
The alternates are M. G. Gichner
and R. Oppenheimer.
The tentative plans of the teams
are for Tingley (chairman), Coffin
and Oppenheimer (alternate) to go
to Virginia to debate the team from
North Carolina—the Hopkins men
upholding the affirmative. In this
case Friedenwald (chairman), Blalock and Gichner (alternate) will
go tp North Carolina to debate Virginia, where Hopkins has the negative of the question.
'Dr. French expressed himself as.
highly gratified with the quality of
the try-out and especially with the
number of men who contested.
More men participated in these tryouts than in any past few years.
Tingley, the chairman of the
affirmative team, is well known in
Hopkins debating circles. He has
been a member of the Adams team
for the past three years, on his
class team twice, on each occasion
lie was successful, and on the winning Varsity team of last year.
Coffin has been on his class team for
two years, but this is his first appearance on the Varsity. Friedenwald, 'to, is comparatively unknown in Hopkins debating, but
made a very good impression in
the try-outs. Blalock, a graduate
student in political science, was a
member of debating teams at the
University of North Carolina. He
is a member of the honorary debating fraternity, the same one that
recently made an effort to establish
a chapter at Hopkins.
There is every reason to believe
that the teams will be succesful, and
will maintain thg Hopkins debating
tradition of unbroken victory, which
the contests of the past three years
has established.

By overwhelmingly defeatin
Swarthmore College last Saturda
in the latter's pool, 4972 points WI
192, the swiming team evened up
matters somewhat with the Pennsyli
vanians for their victory in football,
last fall at Homewood. As Swarth7
more was one of the two teams to
defeat the Black and Blue on the
gridiron, Hopkins tankmen werc
determined to take a fall out b
their opponents, and how well
theyl
succeeded is indicated by the score;
Hopkins started off with a rush
by annexing the 200-yard relay:
Woodward, swimming first for the
Black and Blue, opened a lead
which was increased by his teammates to a safe margin. In the
next event, the plunge for distance,
'Swarthmore secured her only first
place, Dowdell winning with a fine
plunge of 66 feet 3 inches. Penneman, the only Hopkins representative in this event, was a good second
with a distance of 60 feet 10 inches.
The 50-yard dash found Rowland
of Hopkins, the individual star of
the meet, romping off with first
place in good time, with Marshall
close behind.
In the fancy diving, Captain Hofman showed his usual brilliant
form and won by a wide margin.
Murch of Swarthmore and McCormick for Hopkins fought it out for
second place, the former finally winning by the narrow margin of 3
points. The next event, the 50yard breast stroke, saw Rowland
again in the lead, with Ginsberg..
also of Hopkins, second. McCormick and Kirk found little difficulty
in winning 8 more points for the
Black and Blue by placing first and
second respectively in the 200-yard
swim. Woodward, Hopkins' only
entrant in the 50-yard back stroke.
found little difficulty in winning this
race by several yards. In the 10oyard dash, Rowland won his third
first place by swimming a beautiful
race. Doyle of Swarthmore placed
second, while Marshall and Pearson
swam a dead heat for the third position.
Hopkins will swim Haverford
College Saturday night in Baltimore at the Central Young Men's
Christian Association, and if the
form so far displayed by the Black
and Blue tankmen is continued,
another Pennsylvania college will

Editor Tingley Pleased with Work Done
on Hullabaloo—Drawings Complimented by the Engraver—All
Photographs Finished.

The work on the 1916 Hullabaloo
has progressed so well that Editorin-chief Tingley expects to have the
book issued shortly before May 15.
Almost all the articles have been
written and the rest of the material
is now coming in rapidly.
During- the past week representatives of the White Studio of New
York have been engaged in taking
photographs of the members of the
Senior Class, THE-NEws-LF,TTER
Board, the Student Council, the
fraternities, the Athletic Board and
other Hopkins organizations and
clubs. The pictures are being taken
on the top floor of the physics
laboratory, which has been fitted
up as a studio. The pictures of the
various classes were taken at Gilman Hall, Homewood, on last Saturday and the early part of this
week. Although all the photographic work is expected to be completed by today (February 15),
if anything more .has to be done,
it will be attended to by D. R. Vickers, photographic editor of the Hullabaloo.
Some very excellent drawings
have been produced, which have
been complimented by the engraver.
As soon as the cuts for the lacrosSe,
baseball and tennis sections are
sent in, the number of necessary
drawings will be complete. The
Hullabaloo Board urges all to subscribe at once as the price N'ill soon
be raised. At present the price in
full for one copy is $2, if the subscription is entered and remitted
before March 15, 1916. After that
date the subscription price will be
raised to $2.50.

re MacKenzie Bakery

JOHN W. RUSSEI.I., Prop.

226 WEST FRANKLIN STREET
622 NORTH EUTAW STREET

The baseball organization meeting for the season of 1916 will be
held in the trophy room of the gymnasium on Thursday, February 24,.
at 5 o'clock. Captain Lewis R.
Ewing will preside and speeches
will be made by the following: Mr.
Robertson Griswold, Dr. Thomas
R. Brown, Dr. Robert B. Roulston,
Dr. Ronald T. Abercrombie, Coach
Hooper and Manager Allan K.
Chalmers. Some of the old players
are also expected to make a few
remarks and interesting reminiscences will be brought back to the
minds of baseball men of former
years.
The prospects for a championship team are exceptionally bright,
Last year Hopkins carried off the
Maryland baseball championship
by winning every State game. Outside the State, defeat was suffered
at the hands of Gettysburg and
Catholic University. A chance to
even the score with Gettysburg will
be afforded the team at the opening game of the season, but Catholic University is not on this year's
schedule.
Material for the team is promisinf.;. Butler and "Butts- Sutton
are the only regulars of last year's
team who are lost. On the other
hand, several experienced men who
were unable to play last year have
promised t) come out this spring.
Both the medical school and the
Freshman Class are expected to
offer sine valuable players. The
first practice will he held in the cage
and will be continued there until
the weather becomes favorable for
work at 1 lornewood.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEB. 14, 1916.
The Banquets.

ti

With the peaceful and law-abiding banquets of the last two years
to look back upon, it might be
deemed unnecessary to again bring
before the attention of the student
body the strong advisability of such
proceedings. Yet rumors have
been afloat that this year the turbulent banquets of former days will
be revived.
THE NEWS-LETTER is not inclined to put credence in such
rumors—it has too high an opinion
of the calibre of the men and the
spirit of the two lower classes to
believe that either freshmen or
sophomores would have so little regard for the good name of the University as to jeopardize it by any
such a course of action. The belief that, in order to evidence class
spirit, it is vitally necessary to kidnap members of another class on
the night of this banquet, has disappeared. Hopkins has come to
realize that the dangerous notoriety
which follows such expressions of
undergraduate exuberance harms
the University far more than any
mythical gain in class spirit might
be supposed to benefit it.
THE NEWS-LETTER believes in
class spirit, believes in it firmly and
whale-heartedly, and it believes
that such manifestations as have.at-

JUNIOR TEAM HEADING LEAGUE
Games in Interclass Basket-Ball League
Causing Much Interest Improvement Is Being Shown in
All the Teams.

Interclass contests in basket-ball
have been. held before at Hopkins,
but never has there been such interest and enthusiasm shown as marks
the present games in the gymnasium every Tuesday and Thursday
at 5 o'clock P. M. Each class is
represented by a team. Practically
all of the scheduled games from
January 8 have been played and
the series will continue until February 29, 1916.
The juniors are heading the list
as to points, but their playing in the
last two games has not been up .to
the pace which they set at the commencement of the series. The good
Work of Brooks and the all-around
Playing of P. Sutton are valuable
assets to the team. McKewen has
also shown ability in his fast offensive work. The success of the juniors can be attributed to their consistent team work and individual

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 14, 1916.

6
MUSEUM TO BE MOVED IN JUNE

STUDENTS IGNORANT OF THE WAR

Valuable Collection of Archaeological
Antiquities to Be Lodged in Academic
Building at Homewood Great
Care to Be Taken in Moving.

Tests of Bowdoin, Williams and New
York University Reveal Fact That
Students Know Little About
Presant History.

The transportation of the collection in the Archaeological Museum
in McCoy Hall to Homewood will
probably take place in June. Owing
to the fragility of the specimens
and their great value, great care
will have to be taken in their moving. Consequently a number of the
articles, including the collection of
Roman and Greek coins which are
valued at $5,00o, will have to be
carried out by hand.
Dr. Robinson and Dr. Magoffin,
who are in charge of the museum,
are already making their plans.
Each specimen will have to be catalogued and labelled, and then be
boxed by professional packers. The
well-preserved articles, such as
some of the vases and other forms
of pottery, the inscriptions and
marble fragments, can be packed in
excelsior in barrels and boxes and
transported in wagons. The delicate bronzes, the Roman glassware, and some of the more fragile
pieces of pottery, however, will
have to be packed with especial
care, and it is doubtful whether
these can be intrusted to the packers for delivery. Likewise great
care will be required in the packing of the ancient manuscripts and
the mummy, which, on account of
its great age, is in a rather crumbling condition.
The room next to the Donovan
Room in the Academic building at
Homewood is to be the future home
of the collection. Dr. Robinson
hopes to buy new steel cases of the
latest type and have them installed
in this room, but, owing to the present lack of money, it is very doubtful whether this can be accomplished before the removal.

As a result of tests put to the
students of several institutions,
among which were Bowdoin, Williams and New York University,
it has been ascertained that there
exists a pronounced ignorance
among- the students of those universities as to important details of the
European War. This ignorance has
been taken as a manifestation of the
general tendency on the part of the
public to neglect a close study of
affairs in Europe; but, at the same
time, it has called forth severe condemnations of student intelligence.
Some of the questions asked by
members of the faculty at both New
York University and Bowdoin College were as follows:
Where is Gallipoli?
What is the capital of Bulgaria?
In what country is Salonika?
On what sea is Montenegro?
Who is the Prime Minister of
England?
Who is Bethman-Hollweg?
Who is Venizelos?
Who is Poincare?
Who is Briand?
Who is von Hindenberg?
Who is Vivani ?
Name the ruler of Turkey
Name the ruler of Bulgaria.
Some rather surprising answers
were received in the examinations.
One student said that the ruler of
Italy was Victor Emmanuel XXIX ;
another said that Poincare was a
French artist. Forty-two out of
fifty-three students at Bowdoin were
unable to tell in what country Saionika was situated ; and only twenty-three out of a class of fifty-three
could name the ruler of Greece.
In answering the question, "Who
is Venizelos ?" some students said
that he was a French general, others that he was a Mexican rebel.
The name of the commander of the
French army was given as anything
from "Joffery" to "Jeofrey."
The general result of the examination at the University of New
York was this:
"None answered all of the inquiries correctly, while only three obta(ned a grade above 90 per cent.
Of a class of twenty-three freshmen, nine failed, while the average
rank was 63 per cent. Another
class of the same number of freshmen averaged only 52 per cent., and
tbirteen failed to pass, while a class
made up of upper-classmen did as
poorly and averaged a grade of
only 61 per cent."

A Matter of Timing.

A minister in the Highlands of

called to reprove him for it.
"It was wrong to get drunk," said
the parson.
"I ken that," said the guilty person, "but then I dinna drink as
meikle as you do."
"Why, sir, how .is that ?"

"And dinna ye take a glass o'
toddy every night when ye are
